question.title: Can we traverse stack in FIFO order without custom logic?
question.body:
My teammate asked if we can traverse stack in FIFO (First In First Out) order. I say stack itself maintain LIFO order in it but we can traverse it in FIFO manner by using another stack or list. Then we asked the same question with chatgpt. I will discuss one of the solutions Chatgpt provided me. In stack we can call method iterator() which return iterator on the stack. And when we iterate, I was expecting that the answer will be in LIFO order but the actual answer will displayed on IDE is FIFO which makes me amaze. Is this an implementation issue from the side of Java or Oracle? Or is it intentional?

Using Iterator:

Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>();
stack.push(10);
stack.push(20);
stack.push(30);
stack.push(40);
System.out.println("Iterating using Stack's iterator (LIFO order):");
Iterator<Integer> iterator = stack.iterator();
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    System.out.println(iterator.next());
}

Using Pop method:

Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>();
stack.push(10);
stack.push(20);
stack.push(30);
stack.push(40);
System.out.println("Iterating using Stack's pop method");
while (stack.size()>0) {
    System.out.println(stack.pop());
}

After doing R&D, I understand that the iterator() method belongs to vector which stack inherited. So it's implementation came from vector not from stack.

I just want to know that is this right behavior? Java says that its stack follows LIFO order and on the other hand we can traverse it in FIFO order. iterator() method should be override in stack by default and there should be no way to traverse stack by FIFO order inside Java.

Kindly explain your thought on this issue. I am not saying Java is wrong. I just want to know current behavior of stack is ok or there can be an improvement?

answers.body:
Your observations are documented in the javadoc of Stack:

The Stack class represents a last-in-first-out (LIFO) stack of objects. It extends class Vector with five operations that allow a vector to be treated as a stack.

This behaviour is expected and correct, the stack is behaving exactly as documented - a vector being masked as a LIFO structure. From an OO point of view, this is also a wrong implementation - a stack is not a vector, so it should not extend it.

The docs also state that you should prefer the Deque interface, instead of Stack:

A more complete and consistent set of LIFO stack operations is provided by the Deque interface and its implementations, which should be used in preference to this class.

As a general purpose Deque you can use ArrayDeque, suitable for most use cases.

Resizable-array implementation of the Deque interface. Array deques have no capacity restrictions; they grow as necessary to support usage. They are not thread-safe; in the absence of external synchronization, they do not support concurrent access by multiple threads. Null elements are prohibited. This class is likely to be faster than Stack when used as a stack, and faster than LinkedList when used as a queue.

Deque<Integer> stack = new ArrayDeque<>();

question_comments.body: from the javadoc mentioned in first comment: "A more complete and consistent set of LIFO stack operations is provided by the Deque interface and its implementations, which should be used in preference to this class." (and that was already for Java 8, more than 10 years ago) ((assuming java.util.Stack))
Even if you want a stack, you shouldn't be using java.util.Stack. It's a relic.
According to the Stack javadoc, Stack extends Vector. So, Stack inherits all the properties of a Vector. A Queue is an interface that is implemented in a FIFO manner.
